title: CTRL0000042648 - Transcribed Interview of Brian Jack, (February 11, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:02
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
And what you just heard there, Mr. Jack, is that this is being
So that was the notice you just heard that it's
This is a deposition of Brian Jack, conducted by the
House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States
Mr. Jack, could you please state your name and spell your last name for the
Mr. Jack, could you please raise your right hand, and you'll be sworn in for the
Brian Jack, and my last name is spelled J-a-c-k.
Do you swear or affirm the testimony you're about to provide in
this deposition, under penalty of perjury, shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
You can put your hand down.
So this will be a staff-led deposition, and members of the committee may of
course join and ask questions if they so choose.
I'm a senior investigative counsel on the staff.
There are no members on the call, on the deposition right now, but there are two of my
They're both investigative counsel working with me.
We're going to follow the house deposition rules that we've provided to your
Mr. Woodward here with you and any other attorney you have.
So, at this time, I'll ask, Mr. Woodward, if you could come on camera and just
introduce yourself for the record and spell your last name.
Stanley Woodward, W-o-o-d-w-a-r-d, on behalf of Brian Jack.
And, under those rules, you are permitted to have
Now, under the deposition rules, Mr. Jack, neither committee members nor staff
may discuss the substance of your testimony that you provide today unless the
or no one that you appeared today.
Now, you'll have an opportunity to review the transcript of the deposition today
You and your attorney are of course free to tell anyone
But before I begin with asking questions, I'll just describe a few
First, as you've already seen and heard, there's an official court reporter
transcribing what you're saying here today, and she is joining us by Webex as well.
Please wait until each question is asked, whether by me or one of my colleagues or a
member, before you begin your response, and we'll wait until you complete your
response before we ask the next question.
That just helps keep the record clear.
The reporter can't record nonverbal responses such as shaking your head, so it's
important you answer each question with a verbal response, and if you forget to, I'll join
And I'll note for the record that Mr. Raskin has joined the call, the deposition.
Additionally, for the benefit of the record and the court reporter, there may be
times when you say a name or an acronym that I'll just ask you to spell so that we're clear
on what you're talking about, and just excuse me when I do that.
We also ask that you provide complete answers to the best of your recollection.
If the question is not clear, just ask for clarification.
And if you don't know the answer,
If you need a break at any point, whether for comfort or to talk to Mr. Woodward
privately, we're happy to accommodate that.
camera off and go on mute.
We'll do the same, so you can talk in private.
I don't think that the deposition will go very long today, Mr. Jack, but my plan
generally is we can take a break every hour, if you'd like, or otherwise if you ask.
hope is that we're done before lunchtime, okay?
Now, throughout the deposition, we'll be directing your attention to exhibits that

time as you need to refamiliarize yourself with it and read it before you answer any

your screen, just let us know.
that you're appearing here today as a result of?

I also want to remind you, as we do all witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately

Do you have any questions, or Mr. Woodward, any issues we need to address
And since this deposition is under oath,
Mr. Jack, as I understand it, you worked in President Trump's administration.
Was it throughout the entire 4 years?
Could you just walk us through the roles you had in the
administration, starting from the beginning until the time when you left in January of
-- I was Special Assistant to the President --
-- and Deputy Director of Political Affairs.
the President and Deputy Director of Political Affairs.
I then was appointed Deputy Assistant to the President and Director of Political
And I was then appointed Assistant to the President and Director of Political
How long did you have the role of Director of Political Affairs, roughly?
And may I ask, are you referring to Deputy Assistant to the
President/Director of Political Affairs or Assistant to the President and Director of Political
Oh, I was getting confused by the titles.
The last position you held when
you left the administration, how long had you held that role?
I was appointed in September 2020 until January 2021.
And can you describe for us what the Office of Political Affairs in the White
House does, or at least did while you were there?
The Office of Political Affairs monitors public opinion, it collects
political information, and advances the President's policy priorities and agenda.
has existed since 1981 and is in operation somewhat so today.
successor of mine there at the White House today.
And how do you contrast that with -- as I understand, there's an Office of
Legislative Affairs within the White House, otherwise referred to as OLA.
scope of OLA's work during your tenure, compared to what you did in Political Affairs?
The Office of Legislative Affairs, as I understood it, was responsible
for maintaining and advancing the President's agenda on Capitol Hill, whereas my office
was responsible for monitoring and surveying political information and political issues,
issues of importance to the President's constituents across the country.
keeping a finger on the pulse, politically
speaking, to be able to inform the President.
And from your tenure from September of 2020 till January of 2021 when you left
the administration, what was your reporting structure within the Office of Political
Who did you report to, and then how many people were directly beneath you?
Well, as an assistant to the President, by definition, I report to the President,
but, of course, at a staff level, I reported to both Mark Meadows and Jared Kushner.
And how many people did you have directly reporting to you in your office?
Now, did you have an official role or title within President Trump's reelection
But in terms of the role within OPA, did you have to -- did you keep

which the President would be appearing?
